children.subject:
I'll clarify that above! UAW 2865 is the union representing academic student employees across the UC. We push for higher wages, benefits and working conditions for employees, as well as lobby for university and legislative actions to improve education and working conditions in the university. I'm a steward in the union representing the EECS department and have been a TA for a while now.

As for the information, the only mandatory collection is your name and email because we have to verify to the university that the signees are actual students. Your specific responses and comments will be tied to your name and email just by the nature of Google Forms, but you're welcome to submit anonymous feedback here on Piazza and I can set up an anonymous form if you're interested in that as well. We won't consider your responses in combination with your name/email nor present them as such to the administration -- again, the purpose of the identifying information is just to confirm that real people are signing the petition.

Let me know if you have any other questions!
What is UAW 2865? Where will all information collected through the petition form goes to?

history.content:
Hey all,

As many of you may be aware, the university is facing a budget crisis. We in UAW 2865, the union representing academic student employees in the UC system, want to ensure that the EECS, statistics and data science programs have adequate instructional funding to support our courses.

To that end, we're asking you to please read, fill out and share this petition: https://tinyurl.com/cs-funding-petition.

Q: How does the petition help?

A: Given that the university (and in fact the state) is low on money, they have to prioritize funding. We want to make sure we're not left out of the conversation, and historically petitions have helped us get results by calling attention to issues that the student body cares about.

Q: Will this take away money from other departments?

A: Ideally not. In the long term, we can ask the UC Regents to propose a budget to legislators which sets aside money for the program, or we can ensure that the university makes specific pushes to ask for philanthropic donations to the program (as philanthropy has remained high throughout the budget crisis). That being said, in the short term we do want proportional funding to support the sheer amount of students taking these classes. We'll discuss with the campus to assess trade-offs that can be made.

Q: Wasn't there a similar petition last year? Why do we need a new one?

A: Yes, there was! After an arbitrator ruled that 8-hour UGSIs should receive full tuition remission, we sent out a petition to students to gather support for the department. Student support is more valuable than ever given the current budget crisis that the university faces, and our case is a lot stronger if we show recent support.

Q: Is this connected to fee remission?

A: Generally, no; we made a deal with the department in February to temporarily lower fee remission for 8-hour uGSIs to 29% of tuition, rather than the 100% mandated by the arbitrator. The 29% number was the balance point that would allow the university to cut jobs in the short term, and the deal aimed to give the department time to gather funds to sustain 8-hour uGSIs at 100% fee remission in following years. Pushing for funding here can push us towards sustaining full fee remission for 8-hour uGSIs, but more importantly we're trying to gain more instructional support for courses and prevent budget cuts.

Finally, just want to note that our goal is to do what's best for student workers and the broader community. There's a spot on the petition where you can give us feedback and ideas, and don't hesitate to reach out to me via email at sean.obrien@berkeley.edu. Our goal is to represent your interests, and we'd love to hear your input or get you involved.

Stay safe and healthy, and again reach out if you have any questions or comments!

- Sean
